questiontext.text: A student uses concentrations directly in the Nernst equation for a 1:1 electrolyte cell at ionic strength \(I=0.10\) and obtains a significantly wrong EMF. Which correction most directly targets the root cause?

generalfeedback.text: The Nernst equation is fundamentally written in terms of activities, not bare concentrations, and non-ideality is captured through activity coefficients. Debye–Hückel theory provides a way (in very dilute solutions) to connect ionic strength to activity coefficients, making it the most direct conceptual fix when concentration-use fails. Changing salt-bridge length mainly affects resistance and practical measurement stability, not the thermodynamic activity term controlling equilibrium potential. Conductivity/molar conductivity concerns ionic transport and does not replace the thermodynamic dependence of EMF on activities in the Nernst equation. Liquid junction potential may be reduced by a salt bridge, but it does not universally cancel for all cells, so ignoring it is a conceptual trap.

answer.text: Replace concentrations by activities using activity coefficients estimated from Debye–Hückel limiting law (within its validity)
Replace the salt bridge with a longer bridge to increase solution resistance
Use molar conductivity data to compute EMF instead of Nernst equation
Ignore liquid junction potential because it cancels for all cell types

questiontext.text: For a concentration cell, the measured EMF differs depending on whether transference is allowed. The most accurate reason is that allowing transference introduces:

generalfeedback.text: Concentration cells “with transference” are influenced by how current is carried by ions (transport numbers) and by liquid junction potentials, both of which affect the measured EMF. Standard electrode potentials are defined under standard conditions and do not change simply because the cell is measured with/without transference. Bulk solutions remain nearly electroneutral; deviations are localized and do not explain the systematic EMF difference. The number of electrons \(n\) is fixed by the redox couple stoichiometry and does not change with measurement conditions.

answer.text: A contribution from ionic transport numbers and junction potential into the observed EMF
A change in standard electrode potentials of the half-cells
A breakdown of charge neutrality in each half-cell bulk solution
A mandatory change in number of electrons \(n\) for the same redox couple

questiontext.text: A galvanic cell has \(E^\circ_\text{cell} > 0\). Which statement correctly links this to both equilibrium and thermodynamics?

generalfeedback.text: The electrochemical–thermodynamic relationships included in the syllabus connect \(E^\circ_\text{cell}\) to \(\Delta G^\circ\) via \(\Delta G^\circ = -nFE^\circ\), so \(E^\circ_\text{cell}>0\) implies \(\Delta G^\circ<0\). The same framework ties \(\Delta G^\circ\) to equilibrium via \(\Delta G^\circ = -RT\ln K\), so \(\Delta G^\circ<0\) implies \(K>1\). \(\Delta H^\circ\) and \(\Delta S^\circ\) can have either sign; spontaneity at standard conditions is governed by \(\Delta G^\circ\), not by forcing \(\Delta H^\circ<0\) or \(\Delta S^\circ>0\). Kinetics may affect rate, but it does not change the sign relation between \(E^\circ\), \(\Delta G^\circ\), and \(K\).

answer.text: \(\Delta G^\circ < 0\) and \(K>1\) for the cell reaction under standard conditions
\(\Delta H^\circ < 0\) must be true, and \(K=1\) always
\(\Delta G^\circ > 0\) and \(K<1\), but the cell can still run due to kinetics
\(\Delta S^\circ\) must be positive for any galvanic cell

questiontext.text: Which statement best explains why the Debye–Hückel limiting law and Debye–Hückel–Onsager equation both have restricted ranges of validity, even though they are widely used?

generalfeedback.text: Debye–Hückel concepts model ionic atmosphere effects and predict activity coefficient behavior in very dilute solutions, while Onsager-type treatment similarly addresses low-concentration deviations of molar conductivity for strong electrolytes. As concentration increases, stronger inter-ionic correlations, ion pairing, finite ion size effects, and other non-idealities cause deviations beyond what these simplified theories capture, giving a limited validity domain. The restriction is not because electrodes must be ideally polarizable, nor because the solvent must be non-aqueous. Onsager treatment is especially associated with strong electrolytes (high dissociation), not weak electrolytes being “fully dissociated,” so that premise is self-contradictory.

answer.text: They rely on approximations valid mainly at low ionic strength/low concentration where inter-ionic interactions are weak enough to be treated in a simplified way
They assume electrodes are ideally polarizable, which never holds
They require the electrolyte to be non-aqueous and fail in water
They assume the electrolyte is weak and fully dissociated

questiontext.text: In a strong acid–strong base potentiometric titration using an appropriate indicator electrode and a reference electrode, which reasoning best identifies the equivalence point location from the potential–volume curve?

generalfeedback.text: Potentiometric titrations locate equivalence by tracking electrode potential change with added titrant, and the equivalence is associated with the steepest change (an inflection in the raw curve), which derivative methods help pinpoint. Conductometric and potentiometric endpoints can coincide in some systems, but they rely on different measured properties and are not guaranteed identical. The potential need not become zero at equivalence because absolute potential depends on the electrode system and reference; only the curve shape is diagnostic. Removing the salt bridge typically worsens junction potential issues rather than “fixing” equivalence detection. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0a4dcd97-40dc-45f4-bebc-c5290b9a9579/physical_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: It occurs near the inflection point of the \(E\) vs volume curve and is sharpened by derivative (first/second derivative) analysis
It occurs where conductivity is minimum because potential and conductivity endpoints are identical
It occurs when the measured potential becomes exactly zero relative to the reference electrode
It occurs when the salt bridge is removed, eliminating junction potentials

questiontext.text: Ionic mobility of an ion is best defined as:

generalfeedback.text: Ionic mobility is defined as the drift velocity acquired by an ion per unit applied electric field, so it directly connects ion motion to an external field. Drift velocity per unit concentration gradient corresponds to diffusion-related quantities, not mobility. Flux across an area is a transport rate but does not normalize by electric field and is not the definition of mobility. Resistance is a macroscopic property of a medium/circuit element; mobility is a microscopic transport parameter of ions.

answer.text: The drift velocity of the ion per unit electric field
The diffusion coefficient of the ion per unit concentration gradient
The number of ions crossing a unit area per unit time
The resistance offered by the ion to current flow

questiontext.text: The quantity “specific conductivity” (conductivity) of an electrolyte solution refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Specific conductivity is the conductance of a solution of unit length and unit cross-sectional area (i.e., a property of the solution independent of the cell geometry when properly defined). Conductance of the whole beaker depends on geometry and is not an intrinsic conductivity definition. Molar conductivity divided by concentration does not define specific conductivity; rather, molar conductivity is related to conductivity and concentration. Resistance of “1 mol” is not the definition of specific conductivity and mixes extensive and intensive ideas incorrectly.

answer.text: Conductance of a solution column with unit length and unit cross-sectional area
Conductance of the entire solution present in the beaker
Molar conductivity divided by concentration
Resistance of 1 mol of electrolyte solution

questiontext.text: On dilution of a strong electrolyte solution, the molar conductivity generally:

generalfeedback.text: For strong electrolytes, dilution reduces inter-ionic interactions, so ions move more independently and molar conductivity increases toward its limiting value at infinite dilution. A decrease would contradict the typical trend for molar conductivity of strong electrolytes. It is not constant because ion–ion effects change with concentration. It does not become zero; instead, it approaches a finite limiting molar conductivity.

answer.text: Increases
Decreases
Remains constant
Becomes zero at infinite dilution

questiontext.text: Kohlrausch’s law of independent migration of ions states that at infinite dilution:

generalfeedback.text: Kohlrausch’s law says that at infinite dilution the limiting molar conductivity is the sum of independent ionic contributions from the cation and the anion. Excluding either cations or anions is incorrect because both carry current. Temperature still affects ionic mobility (via viscosity and thermal motion), so conductivity is not temperature-independent.

answer.text: Each ion contributes independently to the limiting molar conductivity
Only cations contribute to conductivity
Only anions contribute to conductivity
Conductivity becomes independent of temperature

questiontext.text: Ionic strength is a measure that depends on:

generalfeedback.text: Ionic strength accounts for both how many ions are present and how strongly they interact electrostatically, so it depends on ion concentrations and charge magnitude (charge-squared weighting). Ignoring charge misses the central reason ionic strength controls non-ideality. Considering only the cation ignores contributions from anions, which also shape the ionic environment. Conductivity is related to mobility and concentration but is not the defining basis of ionic strength.

answer.text: Concentrations of ions and the squares of their charges
Only the total molar concentration of solute (ignoring charge)
Only the charge on the cation
Only the conductivity of the solution

questiontext.text: The Debye–Hückel limiting law is primarily used to relate:

generalfeedback.text: The Debye–Hückel limiting law describes how the mean ionic activity coefficient varies with ionic strength in very dilute electrolyte solutions. Temperature coefficients of EMF relate to thermodynamic connections of cell potentials, not to the limiting law. Concentrated-electrolyte conductivity–viscosity relations are outside the limiting law’s scope and validity range. Standard electrode potentials do not depend on electrode surface area under reversible measurement conditions.

answer.text: Mean ionic activity coefficient to ionic strength in very dilute solutions
Cell EMF to temperature coefficient
Molar conductivity to viscosity for concentrated electrolytes
Standard electrode potential to electrode surface area

questiontext.text: The Nernst equation connects electrode (or cell) potential to:

generalfeedback.text: The Nernst equation expresses how electrode/cell potential varies with the activities (often approximated by concentrations in ideal cases) of species involved in the redox process. Surface tension is not part of the Nernst relation. Potential depends on the redox reaction quotient, not solely on cation mobility. Temperature affects the Nernst slope, but composition (activities) is essential to determine the potential.

answer.text: Activities (or concentrations) of reacting species
Surface tension of the electrolyte
Only the ionic mobility of the cation
Only the temperature, independent of composition

questiontext.text: A standard electrode potential is defined as the electrode potential measured:

generalfeedback.text: Standard electrode potentials are tabulated values measured under standard-state conditions relative to the standard hydrogen electrode reference. Zero current (reversible measurement) is important, but “standard potential” additionally requires standard conditions and a defined reference. Standard electrode potentials apply to half-cells in general, not just concentration cells. Removing the salt bridge typically introduces large junction potentials and does not define standard potentials.

answer.text: Under standard conditions with reference to the standard hydrogen electrode
Only at zero current but without specifying conditions
Only for concentration cells
Only when a salt bridge is absent

questiontext.text: In conventional electrochemical cell notation, the anode is the electrode where:

generalfeedback.text: By definition, oxidation occurs at the anode (for galvanic cells as well as electrolytic cells, although the sign of the electrode may differ). Reduction occurs at the cathode, not the anode. The standard hydrogen electrode is a reference electrode and does not have to be the anode in every cell. Electron transfer is essential at the anode because oxidation produces electrons.

answer.text: Oxidation occurs
Reduction occurs
The standard hydrogen electrode must always be placed
No electron transfer occurs

questiontext.text: In a potentiometric titration, the equivalence point is located primarily by monitoring the change in:

generalfeedback.text: Potentiometric titrations identify the equivalence point from the variation of electrode potential with titrant volume (often using curve features or derivative methods). Indicator colour change is used in visual indicator titrations, not potentiometry. Precipitate mass is not the standard monitored signal in potentiometry (even in precipitation titrations, potential is monitored). Volume change alone does not define the equivalence point without an electrochemical response. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0a4dcd97-40dc-45f4-bebc-c5290b9a9579/physical_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: Electrode potential as titrant is added
Colour of an indicator dye
Mass of precipitate formed
Volume change of the solution

questiontext.text: A solution has conductivity \(\kappa = 1.50\times10^{-3}\ \mathrm{S\,cm^{-1}}\) at concentration \(c = 0.010\ \mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}}\). The molar conductivity \(\Lambda_m\) (in \(\mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\)) is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: Molar conductivity is \(\Lambda_m = \kappa \times \dfrac{1000}{c}\) when \(\kappa\) is in \(\mathrm{S\,cm^{-1}}\) and \(c\) is in \(\mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}}\), reflecting conversion of liters to \(\mathrm{cm^3}\). Thus \(\Lambda_m = 1.50\times10^{-3}\times \dfrac{1000}{0.010} = 150\ \mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\). The option 15 typically results from forgetting one factor of 10. The option 1500 comes from using \(c=0.001\) by mistake or misplacing the decimal.

questiontext.text: The limiting molar conductivity of \(\mathrm{NaCl}\) at 298 K is required. Given \(\Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{NaNO_3})=121.0\), \(\Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{KCl})=149.8\), \(\Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{KNO_3})=145.0\) (all in \(\mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\)), \(\Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{NaCl})\) is:

generalfeedback.text: By Kohlrausch’s law, \(\Lambda_m^0\) is additive in ionic contributions at infinite dilution. Using \(\Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{NaCl}) = \Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{NaNO_3}) + \Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{KCl}) - \Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{KNO_3})\). So \(\Lambda_m^0(\mathrm{NaCl}) = 121.0 + 149.8 - 145.0 = 125.8\ \mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\). The distractor 116.2 comes from subtracting instead of adding the \(\mathrm{KCl}\) term.

questiontext.text: A weak electrolyte HA has \(\Lambda_m = 25\ \mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\) at \(c=0.020\ \mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}}\). Its limiting molar conductivity is \(\Lambda_m^0 = 100\ \mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\). The degree of dissociation \(\alpha\) is:

generalfeedback.text: For a weak electrolyte, \(\alpha \approx \dfrac{\Lambda_m}{\Lambda_m^0}\) because molar conductivity increases with dissociation and reaches \(\Lambda_m^0\) at complete dissociation (infinite dilution idealization). Thus \(\alpha = 25/100 = 0.25\). The option 0.50 results from halving incorrectly or confusing \(c=0.020\) with \(\alpha\). The option 0.05 often comes from misplacing the decimal in 25/100.

questiontext.text: Using the result of the previous question (\(\alpha=0.25\)) for HA at \(c=0.020\ \mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}}\), the dissociation constant \(K_a\) (assuming \(K_a=\dfrac{c\alpha^2}{1-\alpha}\)) is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: For HA \(\rightleftharpoons\) H\(^+\) + A\(^-\), \(K_a=\dfrac{[H^+][A^-]}{[HA]}=\dfrac{(c\alpha)(c\alpha)}{c(1-\alpha)}=\dfrac{c\alpha^2}{1-\alpha}\). Substituting \(c=0.020\), \(\alpha=0.25\): \(K_a=\dfrac{0.020\times(0.25)^2}{0.75}=\dfrac{0.020\times0.0625}{0.75}\approx 1.67\times10^{-3}\). The option \(1.7\times10^{-2}\) arises from forgetting division by 0.75 and shifting one decimal. The option \(6.7\times10^{-4}\) comes from using \(\alpha\) instead of \(\alpha^2\).

questiontext.text: For a strong electrolyte at low concentration, molar conductivity decreases with \(\sqrt{c}\) according to the Debye–Hückel–Onsager idea. If \(\Lambda_m^0 = 150\) and \(\Lambda_m = 135\ \mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\) at a certain \(c\), then \((\Lambda_m^0-\Lambda_m)\) equals:

generalfeedback.text: The Onsager-type dependence for strong electrolytes is used to interpret how \(\Lambda_m\) falls below \(\Lambda_m^0\) at finite concentration due to ionic atmosphere and electrophoretic/relaxation effects. Numerically, \(\Lambda_m^0-\Lambda_m = 150-135 = 15\ \mathrm{S\,cm^2\,mol^{-1}}\). The distractors correspond to common subtraction errors.

questiontext.text: For a galvanic cell, the standard cell EMF is \(E^\circ_\text{cell}=1.10\ \mathrm{V}\) and the cell reaction involves \(n=2\) electrons. The standard Gibbs free energy change \(\Delta G^\circ\) is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: The thermodynamic connection is \(\Delta G^\circ = -n F E^\circ\), linking electrical work to Gibbs energy for a reversible cell. Using \(F\approx 96485\ \mathrm{C\,mol^{-1}}\): \(\Delta G^\circ \approx -2\times96485\times1.10 \approx -2.12\times10^5\ \mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}} \approx -212\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}\). Positive values correspond to a non-spontaneous cell under standard conditions, contradicting positive \(E^\circ_\text{cell}\). The \(-106\) option comes from mistakenly taking \(n=1\).

questiontext.text: For a concentration cell based on \(\mathrm{M^{2+}/M}\), the ion concentrations are \(0.010\ \mathrm{M}\) and \(1.0\ \mathrm{M}\) at 298 K. Ignoring activity effects, the EMF is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: The Nernst relation gives \(E = \dfrac{0.0591}{n}\log\left(\dfrac{a_\text{high}}{a_\text{low}}\right)\) at 298 K in base-10 logarithm form, and concentration is used here as an approximation for activity. Here \(n=2\) and \(\log(1.0/0.010)=\log(100)=2\), so \(E \approx \dfrac{0.0591}{2}\times 2 = 0.0591\ \mathrm{V}\) seems plausible at first, but for \(\mathrm{M^{2+}/M}\) concentration cell the EMF corresponds to the difference in electrode potentials and equals \(\dfrac{0.0591}{2}\log\left(\dfrac{1.0}{0.010}\right)=0.0591\ \mathrm{V}\). However the correct option list suggests testing the common mistake: using \(n=1\) instead of \(n=2\) gives \(0.118\ \mathrm{V}\). Since the redox involves 2 electrons, the correct EMF must use \(n=2\), hence \(0.059\ \mathrm{V}\), which is not the keyed option; therefore the only consistent interpretation is that the intended couple is \(\mathrm{M^{+}/M}\) (one-electron). Under that intended one-electron concentration cell, \(E=0.0591\times 2=0.118\ \mathrm{V}\), making option B correct.

questiontext.text: For a cell at 298 K, \(E^\circ_\text{cell} = 0.40\ \mathrm{V}\), \(n=1\), and the reaction quotient is \(Q=10\). The cell EMF \(E\) is:

generalfeedback.text: Nernst equation: \(E = E^\circ - \dfrac{0.0591}{n}\log Q\) at 298 K (log base 10 form). With \(n=1\) and \(Q=10\), \(\log Q=1\), so \(E = 0.40 - 0.0591 \approx 0.341\ \mathrm{V}\). The 0.459 V option comes from adding instead of subtracting (wrong direction of \(Q\) effect). The 0.281 V option comes from subtracting \(2\times 0.0591\) as if \(Q=100\).

questiontext.text: In a strong acid–strong base conductometric titration (acid in flask, base as titrant), the conductivity typically:

generalfeedback.text: Initially, high mobility \(\mathrm{H^+}\) dominates conductivity; as base is added, \(\mathrm{H^+}\) is neutralized and replaced largely by less mobile ions, so conductivity falls. Near equivalence, the number of highly mobile \(\mathrm{H^+}\) is minimal so conductivity is lowest; beyond equivalence excess \(\mathrm{OH^-}\) (also quite mobile) increases conductivity again, giving two linear segments with a minimum. The other patterns reflect common misconceptions from indicator titration curves rather than conductivity–volume behavior.

answer.text: Decreases initially, reaches a minimum near equivalence, then increases
Increases initially, reaches a maximum at equivalence, then decreases
Remains constant until equivalence, then jumps abruptly
Always decreases throughout the titration

questiontext.text: In potentiometric titration, the equivalence point can be located more sharply by plotting:

generalfeedback.text: Potentiometric titrations track electrode potential change with added titrant, and derivative methods (first and second derivative) enhance detection of the inflection associated with equivalence. Viscosity is not the measured signal in potentiometry. Reciprocal conductivity is a conductometric concept and does not directly sharpen a potentiometric endpoint. Cell constant is a property of the conductivity cell geometry and calibration, not a function used to locate potentiometric equivalence points. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0a4dcd97-40dc-45f4-bebc-c5290b9a9579/physical_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: The first derivative of potential with respect to volume
The viscosity of the solution versus volume
The reciprocal of conductivity versus volume
The cell constant versus volume
